sub_topic: Prove that the power set of a set is always larger than the set itself.
message_1: Let A be a set with exactly 3 elements. Using the result from set theory that states the power set of a set is always larger than the set itself, what is the size of the power set of A?
message_2:
The power set of a set A is the set of all possible subsets of A, including the empty set and A itself. For a set with n elements, the size of its power set is 2^n.

In this case, A has 3 elements, so the size of the power set of A is 2^3 = 8.
